round_data.prompt:
You and another agent have to negotiate a division of items between the two of you.
    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 4 units of item 1, 4 units of item 2, 6 units of item 3, 5 units of item 4, 7 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 9 for item 1, 81 for item 2, 9 for item 3, 37 for item 4, 37 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 858. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 658. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.98, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.

Current offer on the table (the amount of each item being offered to you): None

        What is your action? As the first player, your available actions are:
        - WALK to walk away
        - A list of numbers [n1, n2, ...] representing your initial offer (what you give to Player 2)
round_data.response:
I'll explain my reasoning briefly. My goal is to propose a division that guarantees me at least the value of my outside option (658) while “buying” Player 2’s agreement by giving them a package that would be (in expectation) about as good as what they would get if they instead “walked away.” (Recall that if no deal is reached each player gets his outside offer.) Because I value each item differently and – importantly – my “cost” for giving an item away is what I lose relative to my full‐bundle value, I want to “spend” only as much of my own total value (858) on Player 2 as is needed so that my own share is at least 658. In other words, I may sacrifice at most 858 – 658 = 200 points (by my own values).

Looking at my per‑unit values for the five items:
  • item 1: 9 
  • item 2: 81 
  • item 3: 9 
  • item 4: 37 
  • item 5: 37

I want to “pay” Player 2 with items that cost me little. Items 1 and 3 cost me only 9 per unit so these are “cheap” to give away and are likely to be relatively more attractive to Player 2 (since his private values are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101, so his expected value per unit is around 51). In contrast, I very much value item 2 and so I want to keep all 4 units. Items 4 and 5 cost me 37 per unit; so any allocation from these is less attractive (from my perspective) than giving away items 1 and 3. In my available “budget” of 200 points (my loss compared to my full 858‐value bundle) I can “buy” value to Player 2. Giving away all available units of item 1 (4 units) and item 3 (6 units) costs me 4×9 + 6×9 = 36 + 54 = 90 points. That leaves me with an extra “budget” of 110, but because 110/37 ≈ 2.97 I can safely add at most 2 whole extra units (from either item 4 or item 5) before my own share would drop below 658. One way to use that extra margin (while keeping my highest‐value items for myself) is to add one extra unit from item 4 and one extra unit from item 5. 

With that proposal the division is as follows:
  • I give Player 2 all 4 units of item 1 and all 6 units of item 3 (because I value these at only 9 each).
  • I give him 1 unit of item 4 and 1 unit of item 5.
  • I keep all 4 units of item 2, and keep the remaining units of items 4 and 5 (so 4 units of item 4 and 6 units of item 5).

Let’s check my resulting payoff using my private values:
  – item 1: I keep 0 units → 0×9 = 0
  – item 2: I keep 4 units → 4×81 = 324
  – item 3: I keep 0 units → 0×9 = 0
  – item 4: I keep 5 – 1 = 4 units → 4×37 = 148
  – item 5: I keep 7 – 1 = 6 units → 6×37 = 222
Total for me = 324 + 148 + 222 = 694 ≥ 658 (so I do strictly better than my outside offer).

On the other hand, Player 2’s package would be (in terms of unit counts) all of item 1 (4 units), all of item 3 (6 units), plus 1 unit of item 4 and 1 unit of item 5. (I’m not privy to his exact valuations, but since many of the “cheap” items I give him normally have a higher expected value for him – roughly 51 per unit – his expected package value comes to about 4×51 + 6×51 + 51 + 51 = 204 + 306 + 51 + 51 = 612. Although that expected value is a bit lower than the average “outside offer” one might expect for him, it is a starting-point offer and he might have drawn lower private numbers; moreover, further rounds allow for adjustment if necessary.)

With this offer I use my “cheap” items to give Player 2 as much as I can while keeping my own share above my reservation. (In later rounds I could adjust further if needed.) 

Thus, my proposed initial offer is to give Player 2 the following unit allotment:
  item 1: 4, item 2: 0, item 3: 6, item 4: 1, item 5: 1.

My response now is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [4, 0, 6, 1, 1]}

If I simply gave those away and kept items 1 and 4 completely, I’d have:

 item4: 4×78 = 312
 Sum = 384+312 = 696 
(which is well above my fallback but then Player 2’s lot might be too weak compared to his outside offer – its expected average “value” on his side would be roughly 128 if we presumed similar values, which is far below 434.)

To make Player 2’s package more enticing (in expectation) while still keeping my own payoff above 541, I can “give” him a little from an item I value relatively well but where giving up one unit does not hurt too much. For example, if I give him 1 unit of item1 (worth 64 to me) and 1 unit of item4 (worth 78 to me), along with all of items 2, 3 and 5, then my kept bundle becomes:
 • item1: 6–1 = 5 units → 5×64 = 320

which is above the rough average of 434 he might expect from his outside offer.

 – Player 2, on average, gets a bundle worth around 459, competitive with his expected fallback.

I’ll explain my reasoning before stating my offer.

We know from the problem that the negotiation is over 5 item types with totals: 3, 5, 4, 5, and 2 units respectively. My privately‐known per‐unit values are very high on items 1 (85) and 2 (79), moderate on item 3 (30) and item 5 (25), and low on item 4 (10). In order to maximize my own total gain I would like to keep almost everything from the high‐value items (items 1 and 2) while “buying” agreement by offering Player 2 primarily items that I value less (especially item 4, and then some of item 5 and as needed item 3).

Both players have an outside option; mine is 205 and Player 2’s (unknown) is drawn uniformly so its expected value is roughly half of their maximum possible total (with an “average” around 51 per unit, roughly a split of the overall value). In total there are 19 units. Giving roughly half the “units” (about 9–10 units) to Player 2 should be enough to beat their outside option (especially since we are in round 1 with no discounting yet). 

To keep my high‐value items, I choose to keep all of items 1 (3 units) and 2 (5 units). That already amounts to 8 units of high‐value items that I would not want to “sell.” For the remaining items the totals are:
 • Item 3: 4 units available
 • Item 4: 5 units available
 • Item 5: 2 units available
Giving Player 2 a total of roughly 10 units should be enough, but I want to “pay” with items that hurt me least. Item 4 is my least–valuable (10 per unit) so I give away all 5 units of item 4. That gives Player 2 5 units already. Then I add all 2 units of item 5 (my value 25 per unit) so now Player 2 has 7 units. I need 3 more units to reach about 10 total units; from the remaining item 3 (moderate value) I offer 3 of the 4 available units to Player 2 and keep 1 unit for myself.

Thus, my full offer to Player 2 is to receive:
 Item 1: 0 units (I keep all 3)
 Item 2: 0 units (I keep all 5)
 Item 3: 3 units (I keep 1)
 Item 4: 5 units (I give all)
 Item 5: 2 units (I give all)

This gives Player 2 a “package” with 10 units total. Even if Player 2’s unknown values average near 51 per unit, their expected total value from the offer would be around 10×51 ≈ 510, which is above what they might expect from their outside offer. At the same time, I preserve nearly all of the very high–valued items. 

Accordingly, my action in round 1 is to make a counteroffer with the offer vector [0, 0, 3, 5, 2].

I will explain my thinking in detail. I know that if no agreement is reached each player “walks‐away” and gets their “outside offer.” My private outside offer guarantees me 867 units of value. (My maximum “pie” from a full‐allocation of the items is 969 in my own numbers.) Thus any deal I propose must give me at least 867; in other words I must “keep” at least 867 in my own valuation. (I also note that because the negotiation is “discounted” round‐by‐round—with γ = 0.98—a delay will reduce the value, so a good deal now is important.) 

I also note that every item has two “values”: my own private value per unit and (unknown to me) Player 2’s private value (drawn uniformly from 1 to 101). My numbers per unit are:
 • Item 1: 95 (units available: 2)
 • Item 2: 100 (units available: 1)
 • Item 3: 9 (units available: 7)
 • Item 4: 97 (units available: 4)
 • Item 5: 76 (units available: 3)
So if I got all items I’d get 2×95 + 1×100 + 7×9 + 4×97 + 3×76 = 969.

Because I want to “claim” almost all the value while still making the deal acceptable for Player 2, I need to “pay” as little (in terms of my own value) as possible while giving them something they are likely to prefer to what they could get outside. In this bargaining problem their outside offer (and thus their reservation utility) is generated by their own private numbers; we know that on average their total “full‐allocation” value is 867 and so (since their offer is drawn uniformly from 1 to 867) on average their outside offer would be about 867/2 ≈434. (Of course, Player 2 knows their own exact numbers—but I do not.) 

I want to give them items that are “cheap” for me but (on expectation) “more attractive” for them. In my bundle the “cheapest” item is item 3 (my value 9 per unit) even though for Player 2 the per–unit value (unknown to me) will on average be around (1+101)/2 = 51. In effect, every unit of item 3 “costs” me only 9 while “worth” about 51 to them. 

I must “pay” them enough so that the deal is at least as good as their outside option. At the same time, because I am the proposer—and my “threat point” (867) is quite high—I want to claim as much of the high–value items as possible. Unfortunately, if I try to “buy” more surplus by giving away even one unit of an item I value highly (say item 1, 2, 4, or 5) I lose much more for myself. In fact, if I tried to give away any unit other than item 3, I would “pay” somewhere between 76 and 100 in my value, which is not minimal. (A simple check shows that if I want to keep at least 867 out of 969, I can sacrifice at most 969 – 867 = 102 points from my “pie.” Using my low–value item, item 3, at 9 per unit, the maximum I can “pay” is with 7 units – that would cost me 63, leaving me with 969 – 63 = 906, which is comfortably above 867.) 

Thus, my plan is to “give” Player 2 all 7 units of item 3 and keep everything else. This offer gives me a value of 906 (calculated as: 2×95 + 100 + 4×97 + 3×76 = 906) while leaving Player 2 the 7 units of item 3. (For Player 2 the value of these 7 units may vary, but on average 7×51 = 357—and if their private value for item 3 is on the higher side, the bundle could be attractive relative to their outside option.)

I might consider proposing a deal that awards me nearly all of the “high‐value” items (items 1, 2, 4 and 5) because my private unit values are very high on these (95, 100, 97, and 76, respectively) and give up only “low‐value” item 3 (worth 9 per unit) to make the deal attractive to Player 2.

4. In an ideal counteroffer from my perspective I would like to keep all of items 1, 2, 4, and 5 (yielding me a base of 190+100+388+228 = 906) and “give” Player 2 all of item 3 (7 units) so that my total value is 906—discounted to about 888—which is above my outside offer value. However, notice that in the offer already on the table, Player 2 is “keeping” not only item 3 but also all of item 5. So my counteroffer that “gives” him only item 3 ([0, 0, 7, 0, 0]) deprives him of item 5.

5. If I counteroffer so as to keep all of item 5, my utility is good for me; however, it would be less attractive for Player 2 when compared to his own offer in Round 1 (he would have lost his “bonus” of item 5). In order to entice him to accept a counteroffer, I would logically have to concede some of the items he values. Yet even minimal concessions (e.g. giving him a unit from item 5) would drop my total value into a region (when discounting is applied) that is lower than my outside option of 867.

6. Thus, if I try to “buy” agreement by conceding enough to reward Player 2 with a share similar to his previous offer, my post‐discount value falls below 867. Conversely, if I propose a deal that keeps nearly everything I value (for example, a counteroffer of [0, 0, 7, 0, 0] so that I get items [2,1,0,4,3] for myself, valued at 906 pre‐discount or about 888 post‐discount), then Player 2 loses the extra value from item 5 that he previously secured. As a rational responder, he is unlikely to accept a deal that gives him less than his original proposal.

7. Comparing all outcomes:
  – Accepting the current offer gives me about 664.
  – Crafting a counteroffer that would yield me a post‐discount value above 867 forces me to keep all of the high–value items. But such an offer (for example [0, 0, 7, 0, 0]) is far less attractive to Player 2 than his earlier offer because it gives him nothing of item 5.
  – Consequently, if I make a counteroffer, Player 2 is likely to reject it and may then either counter in the final round (when proposals are even less flexible) or walk away. In either case my outcome would be determined by my outside option.

8. Given that my outside offer is 867 (which is better than what I’d get if I accept the current deal or if my counteroffer forces Player 2 to try to extract additional value in further rounds) the rational action is to WALK away.

Thus, my action is to WALK.

I'll explain my reasoning briefly.

We know that all 18 units (5+4+1+4+4) have a total “personal‐value” of 923 for me. My outside option is only 68, so I have a very strong position. In contrast, Player 2’s private values are drawn from UNIF(1,101) so his expected per‐unit value is roughly 51 and his private outside offer (drawn from 1 to his full total value) will often be much higher than my 68. (If we assume his full item total is about 18×51 ≈ 918, then his average outside offer is roughly ½ of that, near 459.) 

My goal is to get as high a share of my 923 as possible while offering Player 2 just enough extra value in the deal so that his share is competitive with his expected outside option. An effective strategy is to “pay” Player 2 using items that hurt me little while (hopefully) giving him a relatively high value. Looking at my private per‐unit values:
 • Item 1: I value each unit at 20 whereas an average opponent unit is worth about 51.
 • Item 4: I only get 2 per unit while the opponent may get roughly 51.
In contrast, I highly value items 2 (95 per unit) and 5 (96 per unit) so I prefer to keep those. (Item 3 is middling at 51, roughly average.)

A minimal “concession” bundle using the “cheapest” items for me is then to hand over all of item 1 (5 units) and all of item 4 (4 units). That bundle “costs” me only 5×20 + 4×2 = 100 + 8 = 108 in my value while giving Player 2 a bundle that (if his values are near the average) is worth 5×51 + 4×51 = 9×51 = 459—roughly equal to what he might expect from his outside option. Meanwhile I keep items 2, 3, and 5 (4+1+4 units) which give me 4×95 + 1×51 + 4×96 = 380 + 51 + 384 = 815. This division clearly beats my outside option of 68.

Thus, my initial offer is to give Player 2 all units of item 1 and item 4, and keep the remaining items. In the required response format I express the items offered to Player 2 as the list [5, 0, 0, 4, 0].

Even though Player 2’s actual per‐unit values are private and drawn uniformly from 1 to 101, a reasonable approach is to “split” the surplus so that my proposal gives Player 2 at least as much (when they eventually discount future rounds) as they might expect by waiting (or by walking away and getting their private outside offer). • A natural idea is to “give” Player 2 the items I value relatively little: namely, all units of item 2 (6 units) and, from the remaining items, consider giving away the ones that would “cost” me less.

  3×77 + 6×38 = 231 + 228 = 459.
Since we’re in round 2 and the discount factor is γ = 0.98 (applied as γ^(r–1) with r = 2) the outcome is worth 459×0.98 ≈ 449.82.
My private outside option is 1219, so accepting 449.82 (discounted) is far worse.

Step 2: As my counteroffer I want a deal that provides me with a “raw” value that, after discounting by 0.98, is at least as good as 1219. In other words, I need a raw value V such that
  0.98×V ≥ 1219 ⟹ V ≥ 1219/0.98 ≈ 1245.9.
(Recall that my total maximum raw value if I got everything would be 1673.)

Step 3: In a counteroffer I specify what I would give to Player 2; whatever I do not offer goes to me. The full available items are: [3, 6, 3, 5, 7]. If my counteroffer is [o1, o2, o3, o4, o5] (units given to Player 2), then I receive:
  item 1: 3 – o1,
  item 2: 6 – o2,
  item 3: 3 – o3,
  item 4: 5 – o4,
  item 5: 7 – o5.
My own raw value is then:
  77×(3 – o1) + 38×(6 – o2) + 66×(3 – o3) + 66×(5 – o4) + 98×(7 – o5).
I need this value to be at least ≈1246.

Step 4: I also consider that in round 1 Player 2 offered me [3,6,0,0,0] (which leaves him [0,0,3,5,7]). Although I don’t have Player 2’s private values, I know that if I make an extremely “lopsided” offer (keeping too much for myself) he might prefer to get his outside offer. Thus I need to give him enough of items he might value while still ensuring I get at least 1246 raw value.

Step 5: Noting that my highest valued items are item 1 (77 per unit) and item 5 (98 per unit), I prefer to keep these. I can concede more of items I value less—item 2 is only worth 38 for me; items 3 and 4 are only 66 each. One plausible counteroffer is to give Player 2:

  • 1 unit of item 3,

  item 4: 5 – 2 = 3  (value: 3×66 = 198),
  item 5: 7 – 0 = 7  (value: 7×98 = 686).
Total raw value = 154 + 76 + 132 + 198 + 686 = 1246.
After discounting in round 2, the value is 1246×0.98 ≈ 1221.08, which slightly exceeds my outside offer of 1219.
